{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3744395,"name":"","username":"Tricks1228","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tricks1228/{size}/258883_2.png","created_at":"2025-09-21T21:41:35.488Z","cooked":"

Apologies if this is the wrong flair.
For a bit of context, my entire time on my team, our programming team has always been just a couple people. For my first two years, it was just me and the programming lead, then last year we had two more join. Now this year, I am the software lead on our team and we got 6 more programmers for a total of 9 of us now.
This is where my question is, I have no experience handling a group of this many. So any tips you all could give would be greatly appreciated!

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2025-09-21T21:41:35.488Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":8,"reads":305,"readers_count":304,"score":146.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":506476,"topic_slug":"how-do-i-handle-a-large-team-of-programmers","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":73462,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"2508 | Co Captain, Programming Lead, Strategy Lead"},"post_url":"/t/how-do-i-handle-a-large-team-of-programmers/506476/1","custom_user_title":"2508 | Co Captain, Programming Lead, Strategy Lead","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3744398,"name":"","username":"nstrike","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nstrike/{size}/167038_2.png","created_at":"2025-09-21T21:48:59.305Z","cooked":"

I am getting all of my programmers on the same page. Even if they claim to be proficient.

  1. w3schools exercises
  2. Codeacademy
  3. 0 to Autonomous
  4. WPILib docs
  5. REV/CTRE Docs (optional with new stuff coming out )
  6. Programming exercises I come up with
  7. Program the old the robot
","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2025-09-21T21:48:59.305Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":301,"readers_count":300,"score":110.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":506476,"topic_slug":"how-do-i-handle-a-large-team-of-programmers","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":51887,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"YAGSL & YASS Creator "},"post_url":"/t/how-do-i-handle-a-large-team-of-programmers/506476/2","custom_user_title":"YAGSL & YASS Creator ","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3744449,"name":"Fatema M","username":"fnmerchant","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/f/d26b3c/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-09-21T22:58:13.070Z","cooked":"

Hi there, we have a software team of over 8ish people, so here’s some ways that we handle a large team of programmers.

Firstly, we split our training into returning and new member training, and have 2 seperate people train those respective groups.

We make slides for new member training that teaches them how to code in Java, and we have more advanced training for returning members that teaches them things like:

  • github best practices
  • robot specific code
  • and how to use AdvantageScope and AdvantageKit

I hope these tips help, and reach out with any questions!

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2025-09-21T22:58:13.070Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":262,"readers_count":261,"score":102.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":506476,"topic_slug":"how-do-i-handle-a-large-team-of-programmers","display_username":"Fatema M","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":75808,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/how-do-i-handle-a-large-team-of-programmers/506476/3","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3744781,"name":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","username":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/slab-mr.thomas/{size}/182153_2.png","created_at":"2025-09-22T02:18:04.519Z","cooked":"

We decided to split by grade (9-10; 11-12) the large team into two smaller teams with a second chassis and second programming team. That keeps more students busy actually making a robot move. As mentioned recently in another thread we sprung for the extra cost of registration fees for a second competitive team so we even have an extra drive team get experience.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2025-09-22T02:18:04.519Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":190,"readers_count":189,"score":58.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":506476,"topic_slug":"how-do-i-handle-a-large-team-of-programmers","display_username":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24594,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/how-do-i-handle-a-large-team-of-programmers/506476/4","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3744813,"name":"Dan","username":"tekdemo","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tekdemo/{size}/138330_2.png","created_at":"2025-09-22T02:47:00.952Z","cooked":"

We’re imperfect at this, but we’ve ran up to teams of 8, and generally 6. It’s certainly a challenge.

  • For new programmers, make sure they have access to hardware and testbenches. You might be able to get making testbenches into your build team’s training.
  • Learn simulation, and have projects that don’t need hardware resources. This helps prevent stalls when there’s conflicts, allocation issues, or something breaks.
  • Git! When the main season starts, git will be invaluable for helping keep multiple people involved on the robot. (there’s a great thread on just this)
  • Encourage work in pairs: We’ve had great luck with pair programming. Just find folks with the same interest and similar skill levels, and make sure they’re swapping between doing the code and helping problem solve/diagnose. This helps promote soft skills, keep harder tasks moving forward, and cuts the number of ongoing projects. This can be important if you’re hardware constrained. Vibes must be minded though, and you can’t let one person do all of the coding.
  • Veterans as mini-mentors: If your mentors are struggling with numbers, get experienced folks to help bring up new folks as a part-time task. Again, soft skill development. But do make sure your veterans have time to work on their own technical skills. Sounds like you guys are already on this road.
  • Keep everyone working toward bigger, long term learning targets, and make sure newer coders get lots of smaller milestones. Veterans burn through milestones, but can figure out their own path to keep busy. Rookies will go through them slower, but will tend to stall out once they finish their current task.
  • Write things down and make it accessible: Set roadmaps, maintain process documentation, and plan ahead. This is my own critical weakness, but every time we buckle down and make it happen, it pays off big time.
","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2025-09-22T02:47:00.952Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":179,"readers_count":178,"score":85.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":506476,"topic_slug":"how-do-i-handle-a-large-team-of-programmers","display_username":"Dan","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":44763,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"2811 Programming Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/how-do-i-handle-a-large-team-of-programmers/506476/5","custom_user_title":"2811 Programming Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3745007,"name":"usbcd36","username":"usbcd36","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/usbcd36/{size}/2444_2.png","created_at":"2025-09-22T14:54:09.161Z","cooked":"

We’re also going through similar growing pains.

  • Practice with whatever time and resources you have. Work to get practice/test environments set up where you can to make this possible – more robots, test boards, or just simulation. Get everyone’s environment to a functioning compile-run-iterate loop before walking away, or you risk wasting time on setup problems. You can come back and teach new project setup later.

  • Everything is new again…to someone who hasn’t done it before. Something that seems trivial to you now (or that the team has done in the past) will still take time for someone new to master. Be patient; give praise. Make it feel good. It’s an accomplishment for them, not for you.

  • Someone has to do the administrative work of tasking/coordinating/checking up/setting bounds/feedback/course-changing-from-feedback/etc…If you are big into the coding aspect and not much into management, that might be a sign to stop and think about this. You might be able to lean on someone else on the team (student or adult who’s generally a good coordinator), or you might have to take a step back from the code to make this work. It’s going to be team-specific too, based on the description of your role (maybe a mentor usually handles this stuff on your team). The goal is to avoid leaving 7-8 people waiting while 1-2 people work on code. Sometimes it’s unavoidable; in that case, keep everyone informed.

  • Set your sights higher than when you had 2-4 people, but not much higher (i.e., definitely not a factor of 9/3 times the features). There is administrative and coordination overhead. Just communicating the goal to 9 people is difficult; you’re going to get twice as many clarification questions. When you factor in feedback, it’s a lot more time. This slows you down, but it’s worth doing.

  • Version control/code-sharing is non-trivial with more people. Commits and pushes to personal branches (i.e., no merges) are things everyone (or every pair) should be able to do independently. Merges and integration come later, and can be assisted. You’ll have more of them because there are more people.

  • Require good descriptions when forming questions (especially “what was expected” vs. “what actually happened”) addressed to you or mentors. The more people, the less of your time (and mentor time) there is to go around, and the more the details should be collected by the person asking the question. Ideally, have people write down the questions, both for time-shifting and because it’s also a form of rubber-ducking.

  • Consider encouraging pair programming for at least some of the people. This feels natural for some people…not so much for others…you’ll need to tailor it to your team. It also means two sets of eyes have hit each piece of code that pair produces, and twice as many minds are debugging (hopefully getting stuck less often). This fits naturally into some tasks – code/iterate together, then one person controls the robot while the other person feeds it game pieces. It also provides a way for people to grow into Git or another VCS; only one of the two needs to know it from the beginning.

  • I advocate for setting up debugging outputs regardless (usually via NetworkTables) but it’s especially helpful when there are multiple people coding. If you push for sensors and internal state to be shown early and up-front, there’s less, “well, it might work if I just change this one thing…” debugging. Also, when you or a mentor finally gets there to help, you don’t have to spend time going through that setup process, or worse, waiting for an intermittent problem to show up. If you use simulation, it’s a much smaller leap – your outputs are already NetworkTables.
